block.p: U.S. Goes to Court to Stop WorldCom Deal for Sprint The Justice Department sought an injunction in federal court against WorldCom's proposed $115 billion acquisition of Sprint, citing concerns that the combined company would stifle competition on the Internet and in the long-distance telephone industry.

The companies said only that they would review their options. WorldCom and Sprint could fight the government in court, but executives from the companies have said that they would almost surely abandon their deal in the face of a Justice Department suit. Shares of WorldCom increased $2.1875, to $39.6875, while Sprint fell $1.1875, to $58.375. [Page A1.]

Oracle Admits Hiring Detective Firm Oracle acknowledged that it had hired a detective firm to investigate groups sympathetic to Microsoft, an effort that yielded documents embarrassing to Microsoft. [A1.]

F.D.A. Reviews Prescription Status Spurred by two pharmaceutical companies that want to take their cholesterol-lowering medications over the counter, the Food and Drug Administration is considering whether many more medicines -- from antibiotics to birth control pills -- should be made available without a doctor's prescription. [A18.]

Media Metrix Plans to Buy Jupiter Media Metrix, an arbiter of who's hot and who's not in the Internet world, will buy Jupiter Communications, an analyst of Internet trends, for $414 million in stock. [C2.]

Stocks Fall in a Technology Slump Stocks ended lower, led by a slide in the technology sector, after a Wall Street analyst cut his estimate for second-quarter revenue at I.B.M. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 38.53 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,504.46. The technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index dropped 53.16 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,858.96. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 4.76 points, to 1,450.55. [C16.]

U.S. Fund to Acquire Japanese Bank The Japanese government said that it would sell the bankrupt Tokyo Sowa Bank to an investment fund led by Wilbur L. Ross, a specialist in corporate rescues, for $331 million. [C4.]

A Competitor, Big on Peaks The Internet life is stressful, says Lewis David Gersh, founder and chief executive of Worldly Information Network, an online financial information company. But he is ''having a blast'' and does not think he has peaked. This man knows his peaks. There was a peak after his junior year of high school. Then there was a higher peak as he was training for a triathlon. What's a little knee surgery after being so sublimely happy? The Boss. [C11.]

Desperately Seeking Accountants Jobs are so plentiful and applicants so scarce that big accounting firms have started grooming talent at high schools, the latest battlefield in a recruitment war. Management. [C11.]

Estimates Raised for Ad Spending Robert J. Coen, a leading forecaster of advertising spending, has raised his estimates for 2000, to a record $235.6 billion, up 9.4 percent from a revised figure of $215.3 billion spent in 1999. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C8.]

A Summer of Waiting in Airports Summertime flight delays are starting to pile up as traffic increases at domestic airports. And despite new strategies for better-coordinated air traffic control responses to weather-related delays, the industry is worried that this summer is going to be one of the worst ever for delays. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C10.]
